Title: 2D vs. 3D: The Effects of Additional Dimension in Visual Field on Information Processing
Session: Message Processing and Persuasion
Title to Check: 2D vs. 3D: The Effects of Additional Dimension in Visual Field on Information Processing
Session to Check: Message Processing and Persuasion
Abstract: Visual information is believed to be processed automatically, using small amount of cognitive resources (Lang, Potter, & Bolls, 1999). This study explores how change in dimension (2D vs. 3D) affects the cognitive load on individuals. Based on the limited capacity model of motivated mediated message processing, or LC4MP (Lang, 2006), an experiment has been designed using video clips varying in its density of structural features and levels of arousing content. The results provides general support for LC4MP, suggesting that additional dimension in the visual field provided by 3D technology do increase the cognitive load in processing mediated messages. To date, this project has collected data from 21 subjects, and will complete with additional forty or more (total N > 60) by ICA 2013.

Title: Aggressive, Combative, and Aggression-Free: Assessing the Validity of the Relational Control- Motivated Aggression Perspective and Violent Couple Typology
Session: High Density: The Dark Side of Interpersonal
Title to Check: Aggressive, Combative, and Aggression-Free: Assessing the Validity of the Relational Control- Motivated Aggression Perspective and Violent Couple Typology
Session to Check: High Density: The Dark Side of Interpersonal
Abstract: The purpose of the present study was to test the construct validity of the Relational Control-Motivated Aggression perspective (RCMA) and corresponding four couple types (Olson, 2004) to determine if the theoretical model was an empirically sound way of identifying different types of aggressive couples. Five hundred and ninety-two individuals completed an online survey instrument. In general, results revealed significant relationships in the expected directions between couple types and relational control, power, trait verbal aggressiveness, and relational happiness. The dimensional approach to relational control was also supported and provided an additional mechanism for further discerning patterns across violent couple types. Thus, the findings from this study support many of the basic structures of the RCMA, namely the control dimensions and several couple types. Theoretical and practical implications are discussed.

Title: An Exploration of Concealment and Discovery in Romantic Infidelity
Session: Advances in Deception and Deception Detection
Title to Check: An Exploration of Concealment and Discovery in Romantic Infidelity
Session to Check: Advances in Deception and Deception Detection
Abstract: Infidelity is not only a pervasive phenomenon in romantic relationships, but is often marked by secrecy, deception, and discovery. The current study had two overarching goals: (1) to uncover concealment strategies used by individuals engaging in infidelity, and (2) to understand the process of information-seeking from the perspective of the partner. Content analysis indicated that individuals use several concealment strategies simultaneously to hide their infidelity. Verbal strategies, including bald-face lies and equivocation were reported most frequently. Analysis of the partner’s experience of the discovery of infidelity corresponds with the Theory of Motivated Information Management; that is, suspicious behavior and a desire to know the truth trigger subsequent information-seeking actions. Infidelity encompasses more than just a violation of a sexual or emotional contract between partners; secrecy, deception, and discovery are often involved in many individuals’ experiences. The current study expands our understanding of this event through an exploration of its correlates.

Title: A Study of 3D HDTV Adoption: An Analysis of Predictors, Perceptions, and Behavioral Intention
Session: Communication and Technology Interactive Poster Session
Title to Check: A Study of 3D HDTV Adoption: An Analysis of Predictors, Perceptions, and Behavioral Intention
Session to Check: Communication and Technology Interactive Poster Session
Abstract: 3D HDTV is a new form of TV viewing technology. This study applied Rogers’ (2003) innovation-decision process model to examine the effects of potential predictors and individuals’ perceptions about 3D HDTV on the behavioral intention of adopting 3D HDTV. Survey responses from 188 participants were analyzed and the research results show that participants had a relatively high level of knowledge about 3D HDTV. Rogers’ five characteristics of an innovation—relative advantage, compatibility, complexity, trialability, and observability—are positively related to the behavioral intention of adopting 3D HDTV. Individuals who have less knowledge about 3D HDTV, who are more innovative, who have more favorable attitude toward 3D HDTV, and who perceive less cost of watching 3D HDTV and perceive fewer health concerns about using 3D HDTV are more likely to adopt 3D HDTV. Gender was not found to have significant effect on adoption intention. This study also found that the use of video-related technologies such as HDTV and video game player are positively related to the adoption intention. The findings of a regression test suggest the perception about relative advantages of 3D HDTV and the attitude toward 3D HDTV can effectively influence individuals’ behavioral intention when controlling for other predictors.

Title: Beware of the Spirits That You Call! Explorations Into the (Dis)ordering Properties of Communication
Session: Communication Constituting Organizations: The CCO Perspective
Title to Check: Beware of the Spirits That You Call! Explorations Into the (Dis)ordering Properties of Communication
Session to Check: Communication Constituting Organizations: The CCO Perspective
Abstract: This paper proposes to study the constitution of organization by acknowledging the fundamentally intertwined nature of order and disorder. Adopting a dialectical approach, which underlines the (dis)ordering nature of organization, the paper explores the mediating role of communication by focusing more specifically on the symbolic and the material dimension of language use as expressed in texts. Taking a communication-centered approach – mainly inspired from the “CCO” perspective (“communicative as constitutive of organizations”) –, the paper shows that efforts/effects of ordering are continuously haunted by disordering, that is, the plurality of many potential orders, which are at work in communication. Relying on the empirical material of three qualitative case studies in three distinct project-based organizations, it accounts for the key and yet paradoxical role of ordering devices, which are designed to create and maintain order, and because of their language-based nature, generate contingency and undecidability (in the same or in a neighboring domain), at the same time.

Title: Call Your Legislator: A Field Experimental Study of the Impact of Citizen Contacts on Legislative Voting
Session: Political Communication Interactive Poster Session
Research Areas: Civic Engagement, Politicians / Legislatures, Quantitative - Other. Please specify:
Title to Check: Call Your Legislator: A Field Experimental Study of the Impact of Citizen Contacts on Legislative Voting
Session to Check: Political Communication Interactive Poster Session
Abstract: We test whether or not citizen contacts influence policymaker behavior. Our design involves random assignment of (state removed) legislators to be contacted by their own constituents about a bill under consideration by the state legislature at the time of the study. The field experimental design allows us to produce internally valid estimates of the influence of constituent contacts on legislative voting. The estimated effect is substantial: being contacted by constituents increases the probability of supporting the relevant legislation by 12 percentage points. The probability that a legislator votes for the legislation increases as the number of calls increase, although at a declining rate. We discuss the theoretical and normative implications of this result as well as suggestions for future research.

Title: Cinema With a Capitole C: A Cultural Economics Analysis of the 1953-1971 Capitole Ledgers
Session: Communication History High-Density Panel
Title to Check: Cinema With a Capitole C: A Cultural Economics Analysis of the 1953-1971 Capitole Ledgers
Session to Check: Communication History High-Density Panel
Abstract: This paper, which is inspired by recent research trends within the field of film studies, concentrates on the analysis of a unique set of archival material coming from the ledgers of the now defunct movie theatre Capitole in the city of Ghent, Belgium, for the period of 1953 to 1971, a period characterized by the arrival of television and the decline of film attendance. Based on a cultural economic analysis, this paper characterizes Capitole as a first-run cinema with a broadly appealing program, maximizing revenue and attendance. This paper aims to make a contribution to the advancement of cultural economics in film studies by connecting cinema and the sociocultural space through an economic perspective.

Title: Communicative Leadership: Leaders and Members Reflecting on Leadership and Communication
Session: Follow Me: Leadership Communication and Rhetoric in Organizations
Title to Check: Communicative Leadership: Leaders and Members Reflecting on Leadership and Communication
Session to Check: Follow Me: Leadership Communication and Rhetoric in Organizations
Abstract:
Despite several studies considering leadership discourse in organizations, the discursive construction of leadership communication by organizational actors is still under-researched. In this study, applying a social constructionist perspective to leadership and drawing from discursive leadership theory (Fairhurst, 2007) we investigate how leaders and employees in two Swedish organizations discursively construct a “communicative” leader. Data from Organization A consists of 17 individual interviews with leaders and 16 focus group interviews with employees. In Organization B, data include eight interviews with leaders and four employee focus groups. Using qualitative methods, we identify different dimensions of communicative leadership, compare leaders’ and members’ understandings of the concept, and compare how communicative leadership emerges in the two organizations. Findings illustrate the situatedness and socially constructed nature of leadership and leader behaviors, and show how co-constructed notions of leadership behaviors or leadership communication influence the communication environments of organizational actors.

Keywords: leadership, communication, discourse, communicative leadership

Title: Could Wild Horses Drag Access Away From Courtrooms? Expanding First Amendment Rights to New Pastures
Session: Rights to Information and Access: Interpretation, Implementation, and Use
Research Areas: Free Speech/Expression, Right to Information/Freedom of Information
Title to Check: Could Wild Horses Drag Access Away From Courtrooms? Expanding First Amendment Rights to New Pastures
Session to Check: Rights to Information and Access: Interpretation, Implementation, and Use
Abstract: When the Supreme Court of the United States decided Richmond Newspapers v. Virginia in 1980, Justice John Paul Stevens declared it “a watershed case.” For the first time, the Court in Richmond Newspapers identified a First Amendment right to gather news – and, in particular, a right of access for the press and public to attend criminal trials. Although Justice Stevens apparently held high hopes for the newly created right of access, in the immediate aftermath of Richmond Newspapers, it appeared that the right would be limited to trials and other judicial proceedings. But an interesting development is occurring with Justice Stevens’ prediction. Slowly but surely, some lower courts are expanding the scope of the First Amendment right of access. This paper analyzes the Supreme Court’s creation of First Amendment right of access and explores the rise of First Amendment access in new domains outside of the judicial branch.

Title: Debating Darija: Telquel and Language Politics in Modern Morocco
Session: Innovations and Struggles for African and Middle Eastern Journalism
Research Areas: Public Sphere, Media system/media culture, International/comparative research
Title to Check: Debating Darija: Telquel and Language Politics in Modern Morocco
Session to Check: Innovations and Struggles for African and Middle Eastern Journalism
Abstract: “Debating Darija: Telquel and Language Politics in modern Morocco” examines the role of Darija, or Moroccan Arabic, in forming modern citizen/subjects in relation to a democratic public sphere. The research questions for this project are: When and how does the francophone newsmagazine Telquel use Darija in its stories? How does Telquel engage in and position itself as a leader in the debate about language policy in Morocco? Textual analysis of Telquel over a one-year period (2010-2011) is used to investigate how language and power are defined by various groups, how people are included or excluded from those definitions, and how Moroccan identity is debated in a moment of globalization and in the context of recent social movements in the Arab world. This study argues that Telquel is endorsing a modernist project of normative democracy and acting as a space of intervention aimed at pulling together multiple cultural and political spheres.

Title: Diverse Perspectives on Presence and Telepresence: An Introduction
Session: Diverse Perspectives on Presence and Telepresence Research, Theory, and Application
Title to Check: Diverse Perspectives on Presence and Telepresence: An Introduction
Session to Check: Diverse Perspectives on Presence and Telepresence Research, Theory, and Application
Abstract: This introduction to the panel will provide an overview of the evolution, current status and prospects for future study and application of the (tele)presence concept. Scholarship around presence is increasing, and increasingly important. as the range of available modes of communication via technology multiply at the beginning of the 21st century. Many, though not all, of us will soon have the ability to interact with real or artificial people, places and events with a nearly limitless set of choices of sensory channel, setting and quality. The presentation will briefly review the ‘big picture’ of presence – how its phenomena, concepts, literatures, institutions and research and professional communities have evolved and predictions about what’s next.

Title: Eggnog and Community: A Case Study of Local Digital Commentary and the Emerging Role of Television
Session: Top Theme Papers 2013: Challenging Communication Research
Title to Check: Eggnog and Community: A Case Study of Local Digital Commentary and the Emerging Role of Television
Session to Check: Top Theme Papers 2013: Challenging Communication Research
Abstract: This study examined news-oriented digital commentary through the theory of the public sphere and the related concept of geographically centered journalism as an important ingredient in invigorating the sphere. The study examined the overall presence of digital commentary in specific community as well as examined in-depth a specific episode in which community members rose up to challenge a television station’s reporting. Overall, this study found four conditions present in connection with robust dialogue: A spark, something around which an audience can coalesce; a place where such conversation is expected; policies that allow relatively unfettered communication and a sufficient mass of audience to keep the sphere inflated and energized. In addition, this study found that the medium was incidental to this process. Further, this study also found little dialogue taking place during routine times.

Title: Examining Korea’s 2012 Presidential Election Campaigns Using (Negative) Entropy Indicator
Session: Preconference: New Media and Citizenship in Asia: Researching the Practices, Functions, and Effects of the New Media in Asian Politics
Title to Check: Examining Korea’s 2012 Presidential Election Campaigns Using (Negative) Entropy Indicator
Session to Check: Preconference: New Media and Citizenship in Asia: Researching the Practices, Functions, and Effects of the New Media in Asian Politics
Abstract: Han Woo Park (Yeungnam U)

Title: Features, Blogs and User-Generated Content Might Not Save Journalism: Evidence From a Comparative Study of the Supply and Demand of Online News
Session: News Audiences and New Media: What Do Users Want?
Title to Check: Features, Blogs and User-Generated Content Might Not Save Journalism: Evidence From a Comparative Study of the Supply and Demand of Online News
Session to Check: News Audiences and New Media: What Do Users Want?
Abstract: This study examines relative prevalence of different storytelling formats in the supply and demand of online news; how they combine with various subject matters; and the extent to which there is a gap between the journalists’ and consumers’ preferences on twenty sites from seven countries. We find that, contrary to the idea that the “news has gone soft,” the narratively sparse and fact-loaded straight news format is the dominant storytelling option for both journalists and consumers. By contrast, the newer storytelling options such as blogs and user-generated content exhibit extremely low levels of popularity among both groups. Moreover, there is a gap between the supply and demand of online news: journalists oversupply straight news that deal with public affairs topics and undersupply other format-content combinations. These findings contribute to the study of journalism by shedding light on the dynamics of agenda-setting and public affairs information dissemination in high-choice media environments.

Title: From Monophonic to Jazzy Integrated Communications
Session: Public Relations and Communication Channels
Title to Check: From Monophonic to Jazzy Integrated Communications
Session to Check: Public Relations and Communication Channels
Abstract: Within corporate communications, two contradictory tendencies appear to be asserting themselves. On the one hand, many companies are concerned with integrating their PR and marketing communications, so as to speak with one voice, while on the other, many companies make a virtue of their differences, both within and outside the organisation. In this paper, we will examine four different approaches to integrated communications which relate in different ways to these trends. The various approaches are typologised with the help of musical metaphors. The four forms are: monophonic, unison, polyphonic and jazzy integrated communications. Both theorists and practitioners are drawn upon in the examination, as well as intermediate positions – theoretical practitioners and practical theorists.

Title: Governing the homo economicus; Consumer representations in bank advertisements
Session: Preconference: Exploring and Remaking Critical Studies of Advertising
Title to Check: Governing the homo economicus; Consumer representations in bank advertisements
Session to Check: Preconference: Exploring and Remaking Critical Studies of Advertising
Abstract: This presentation is about historical consumer portrayals in Finnish print advertisements of banks. Drawing from Foucaultian studies of governmentality and critical studies of consumer culture, I view advertising as a form of government. Advertisements hail the viewers as consumers; the marketers aim at mobilizing people as consumers by constructing particular forms of subjectivity. The data covers bank advertisements in 1954 – 2008 in the leading current affairs weekly magazine Suomen Kuvalehti and the human interest weekly Apu. As result, from 1950’s to 1980’s the consumers were represented mainly as rational subjects (homo economicus), yet they were addressed as wards by the banks. Alongside a representation of an emotion-driven consumer (homo emotiocus) was increasingly visible in particular from the 1980’s. This is when the Customer Relationship Marketing took over in marketing thinking and the consumers were addressed more as equals like partners.

Title: How Journalists‘ and Scientists‘ Views on Objectivity Influence Their Accounts of Reality
Session: Journalism Studies Interactive Poster Session
Research Areas: Journalistic norms/routines, Bias in News, Quantitative approach
Title to Check: How Journalists‘ and Scientists‘ Views on Objectivity Influence Their Accounts of Reality
Session to Check: Journalism Studies Interactive Poster Session
Abstract: Authors have suggested that the quality of news would increase if journalists adopted scien-tific standards or, specifically, a scientific definition of objectivity. A quasi-experimental sur-vey of 134 German journalists (34 %) and 163 scientists / scholars (33 %) from different sub-ject areas was conducted to investigate a) how much the professionals commit themselves to objectivity, b) how they define objectivity and c) if a scientific understanding of objectivity improves journalists’ news decisions. Results suggest the contrary. Journalists and academic professionals are highly committed to objectivity but have different understandings of it. The more journalists subscribe to the definition that is prevalent in their profession, the more they criticize exaggerated or selective accounts of reality. The more journalists accept academics’ criteria of objectivity the more they seem to excuse exaggerated or incomplete accounts. Moreover, a strong commitment to objectivity enhances criticism toward exaggerated or selective accounts in both professions.

Title: Imagological thinking: Sampo in branding and advertising
Session: Preconference: Exploring and Remaking Critical Studies of Advertising
Title to Check: Imagological thinking: Sampo in branding and advertising
Session to Check: Preconference: Exploring and Remaking Critical Studies of Advertising
Abstract: Concept is the field of organised/structured associations and connotations around a certain semantic center. Every concept can be described by means of the semantic differential analysis (i.e., the Tucker standard test). All possible concretions (visualisations) of these conceptual associative and connotative clusters form the imagological potential. From this imagological menu of outwardly different but semantically related potential concretions (visualisations) _ so-called allotropes _ an image-maker (brand-builder) can choose the most favorables to initiate the implicit story-telling as a new brand awareness of the audience. The mechanism of conceiving and generating stories operates in the most efficient way as the Sampo of the Finnish epic _ as a hidden quern grinding flour, salt and money of thin air.

Title: Internet Aggregators Constructing the Political Right Wing
Session: Preconference: New Media and Citizenship in Asia: Researching the Practices, Functions, and Effects of the New Media in Asian Politics
Title to Check: Internet Aggregators Constructing the Political Right Wing
Session to Check: Preconference: New Media and Citizenship in Asia: Researching the Practices, Functions, and Effects of the New Media in Asian Politics
Abstract: Muneo Kaigo (U of Tsukuba)

Title: “I Want to Go Out With You” vs. “I Want to Talk to You”: Corpus Analysis of Gender Differences in Mobile Text Messages of Adolescents
Session: Sex and Romance and Sexual Identity: Exploring Links With Media (High Density Session)
Title to Check: “I Want to Go Out With You” vs. “I Want to Talk to You”: Corpus Analysis of Gender Differences in Mobile Text Messages of Adolescents
Session to Check: Sex and Romance and Sexual Identity: Exploring Links With Media (High Density Session)
Abstract: The objectives of this study are (1) to investigate gender differences in mobile texting behavior among adolescents and (2) to examine a novel methodology – corpus comparison analysis – in analyzing mobile-phone-based interactions. Applying corpus comparison method, the present study especially delineates patterns of expressions used in actual text messages. Results revealed that gender differences persist in texting behavior: (1) girls exchange more messages than boys do; (2) girls are more likely to develop and maintain relationship through texting, whereas boys use text messages mainly for flirting; (3) language which girls used in texting includes more self-disclosure of their emotions and personal information; (4) expressions for politeness occur more frequently in girls’ text messages. Theoretical explanations of gender differences in mobile texting are provided. The strengths and limitations of keyword comparison method are discussed as well.

Title: Letting Go of Superwoman: Embodying the Mother-Child Dyad
Session: Gender Blind/Gender Vision: One Step Forward
Title to Check: Letting Go of Superwoman: Embodying the Mother-Child Dyad
Session to Check: Gender Blind/Gender Vision: One Step Forward
Abstract: This chapter is a work in progress. This is an excerpt from Reviving the Self: Beyond the Wandering Womb (working title of a book in progress). In Chapter 2: Letting go of superwoman: Embodying the mother-child dyad, I present findings from 44 in-depth interviews with biological mothers of newborns to understand how the mother-child dyad impacted their meaning making of health. Participants acknowledged the intrinsic duality of the mother-child dyad and reformulated traditional expectations of “putting the baby first.” This chapter weaves an eclectic mix of feminist theory and scholars, including Foucault, Pollock, Martin and Friedan to explicate how women make meaning of medicalization. Participants described a contest over their bodies in relation to diet and exercise before, during, and after pregnancy. These women resisted the biomedical paradigm in various ways, such as through trusting their bodies and valuing storytelling and personal narrative as a form of expertise.

Title: Making the World a Distant Place? How Foreign TV News Affects Individual Cynicism in Post-Colonial Hong Kong
Session: Covering the World: Foreign Correspondents and Foreign News
Research Areas: Bias in News, Media Effects - Other, Quantitative approach
Title to Check: Making the World a Distant Place? How Foreign TV News Affects Individual Cynicism in Post-Colonial Hong Kong
Session to Check: Covering the World: Foreign Correspondents and Foreign News
Abstract: This paper examines the psychological impact of foreign television news on political cynicism in Hong Kong. We hypothesize that exposure to the prevalent negative events and conflicts in international news will lead to the audience’s cynical perception of the world. Given Hong Kong’s colonial history and its highly mobilized population, we further investigate the role of individual globality and immigration status in the process. A random digit dialing telephone survey was conducted in 2009 to select a sample of 600 Hong Kong residents aged between 18 and 70. The results showed that individual attention to foreign news of deviants was positively associated with political cynicism among those first-generation immigrants who were born in mainland China or elsewhere, but negatively related among local Hong Kongers. The implications of the findings were discussed.

Title: Media Cues and Citizen Support for Right-Wing Populist Parties
Session: Immigration, Racial Attitudes, and Right-Wing Populism
Research Areas: Political Behavior - Other, Elections / Campaigns, Media Effects - Other
Title to Check: Media Cues and Citizen Support for Right-Wing Populist Parties
Session to Check: Immigration, Racial Attitudes, and Right-Wing Populism
Abstract: Right-wing populist parties are thriving across Europe. Usual explanations for the success of these parties are based on notions related to economics, national identity or cultural alienation. Some authors, however, have shown that the mass media also play a significant role. Whereas these studies provide evidence drawing on macro-level data resources and/or qualitative accounts, there is little systematic evidence about how mass media coverage may affect support for the populist right on the level of the individual voter. The current study adds to the existing literature on media and political populism by 1) its individual-level focus, 2) the use of an experimental design employing multiple cues: an immigration cue, an anti-politics cue and a party cue, and 3) by drawing on explicit and implicit data for party support. We find effects of certain cues on both implicit and explicit support for far right parties, moderated by political knowledge.

Title: m-Health: A Systematic Review of the First 10 Years of Research
Session: Diverse Facets of ICT Use (CAT High Density Panel II)
Research Areas: Mobile Media, Health Communication, Internet / New Technology
Title to Check: m-Health: A Systematic Review of the First 10 Years of Research
Session to Check: Diverse Facets of ICT Use (CAT High Density Panel II)
Abstract: In the last decade m-Health has expanded as a part of e‐Health. Yet, systematic research on the impact of mobile technologies on health outcomes remains scarce. The objective of this study was to provide a comprehensive view of what has been done so far, and to understand how the introduction of new smartphones has changed research in the field. A systematic literature review was conducted on a sample of 117 articles published between 2002 and 2012 to understand the main impact areas of mobile technologies, the methodology and the features used, and the type of outcome measures adopted. Results showed that the research interest towards m‐Health is growing, however the new opportunities offered by new mobile technologies do not seem to have been explored so far. Mapping the evolution of the field permits a better understanding of its strengths and weaknesses, and can inform future developments.

Title: My Privacy is Okay, But Theirs is Endangered! Social Origin of Online Privacy Concern and its Behavioral Implications
Session: Privacy and Trust in the Online Environment
Title to Check: My Privacy is Okay, But Theirs is Endangered! Social Origin of Online Privacy Concern and its Behavioral Implications
Session to Check: Privacy and Trust in the Online Environment
Abstract: On the Internet, people’s activities are easily traced and collected, and online privacy infringement (i.e., improper use of personal information) has been reported in advanced societies. Based on prior studies on risk perception, this study examines comparative optimism of online privacy infringement (i.e., users tend to believe privacy infringement is less likely to happen to the user than others), and its antecedents and consequences. Relying on large scale online survey data in South Korea (N = 2,028), this study finds that (1) comparative optimism is enlarged as the targeted others are younger, (2) online knowledge and others-caring personality increases comparative optimism by mainly influencing perceived target risk and prior experience of privacy infringement increases comparative optimism by mainly influencing perceived personal risk, and (3) comparative optimism is related with both more adoption of privacy-protective behaviors and support for government regulatory policy on the use of online information.

Title: News Media Use and the Informed Public in the Digital Age
Session: Changing Media Environments, Changing Media Use Patterns
Research Areas: Political Knowledge & Sophistication, News / Journalism, Internet / New Technology
Title to Check: News Media Use and the Informed Public in the Digital Age
Session to Check: Changing Media Environments, Changing Media Use Patterns
Abstract: Questions concerning the primary sources of political information and their efficacy are of perennial concern in political communication research. Although research in this area is known for a number of stable patterns, we argue that these are under greater strain than ever before, and that key assumptions about how individuals acquire political information from the media must be continually investigated. In this paper, we use data from a nationally representative online survey to provide just such a reexamination of relationships between news media use and political knowledge. We find that by some measures, directed internet searches have come to rival television news as a source for information, and that newspapers no longer appear to have the strongest educative influences. In addition to providing an updated assessment of media use and political knowledge patterns, we consider the implications of our findings for contemporary theoretical discussions within the field of political communication.

Title: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Title to Check: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session to Check: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Abstract: Research has shown that medical students like to watch medical dramas, but there is some concern about how this might eventually affect their professional behavior. The aim of the current study is to provide insight into the moral evaluations of medical dramas by medical students and physicians in order to formulate if and how medical dramas might be used as a tool in ethics education, thereby bringing clarity to the discussion over the proposed merit it could have in such a curriculum. A qualitative study was conducted that included in-depth interviews (N = 40) among a divers sample of medical students and physicians. The results show that the moral evaluations of a medical drama changed over time due to more (theoretical and practical) knowledge and experience and therefore a more nuanced view of the profession and professional ethics.

Title: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Title to Check: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session to Check: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Abstract: Research has shown that medical students like to watch medical dramas, but there is some concern about how this might eventually affect their professional behavior. A qualitative study was conducted that included in-depth interviews (N = 40) among a divers sample of medical students and physicians. Title: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Title to Check: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session to Check: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Abstract: Research has shown that medical students like to watch medical dramas, but there is some concern about how this might eventually affect their professional behavior. The aim of the current study is to provide insight into the moral evaluations of medical dramas by medical students and physicians in order to formulate if and how medical dramas might be used as a tool in ethics education, thereby bringing clarity to the discussion over the proposed merit it could have in such a curriculum. A qualitative study was conducted that included in-depth interviews (N = 40) among a divers sample of medical students and physicians. The results show that the moral evaluations of a medical drama changed over time due to more (theoretical and practical) knowledge and experience and therefore a more nuanced view of the profession and professional ethics.

Title: Sweden: Are Direct Press Subsidies the Preferred Solution?
Session: Policy Failure in Confronting the Journalism Crisis: Evidence From the US and Europe
Title to Check: Sweden: Are Direct Press Subsidies the Preferred Solution?
Session to Check: Policy Failure in Confronting the Journalism Crisis: Evidence From the US and Europe
Abstract: Direct press subsidies to second-ranking newspapers in the market are undoubtedly one of the most distinctive features of Swedish media policy. They have been used since 1971, when a political majority from the Social Democratic Party and the Centre Party reached on agreement in the Parliament. The system has always been highly controversial; perceived either as an attack on the free press or as a guarantee for pluralism in the market. In recent years, digital media developments and EU media policy have put the press subsidy system and its basic principles under new pressures. The efficiency of the system is also disputed. The subsidies have saved newspapers with economic problems and the decrease in newspaper titles in Sweden is not as articulated as in many other countries. On the other hand, the system has not affected media ownership concentration and most subsidized newspapers are today owned by commercially successful companies.

Title: The 3-Ds of Globalized Bollywood: Digitalization, D-Cinema, and the Demassification of South Asian Cinematic Public Spheres
Session: Bollywood in the Digital Era: Shifting Global Practices and Perspectives
Title to Check: The 3-Ds of Globalized Bollywood: Digitalization, D-Cinema, and the Demassification of South Asian Cinematic Public Spheres
Session to Check: Bollywood in the Digital Era: Shifting Global Practices and Perspectives
Abstract: Given rapid developments in technology, digital cinema – or D-cinema – is now supplanting celluloid-based technological and social infrastructures throughout the world (Radjadhyaksha, 2009; Rai, 2009). In the post-liberalized Indian film industry, which gained official economic recognition in 1998, proponents assert that digital technologies are revolutionizing the popular Hindi film industry, particularly through the expansion of online streaming services, mass retailing of DVD and blu-ray discs, and construction of multiplex cinemas that feature high-definition digital and 3-D stereoscopic viewing options, as has been the case elsewhere in Asia (Curtin, 2009; Ganti, 2012; Rai, 2009; Stephanie, Sharma, & Ramasubbu, 2012). However, critics assert that such technologies also threaten to demassify consumption practices in South Asia, disrupting democratic viewing traditions within these cinematic public spheres (Ganti, 2012). In this presentation, I explore the technological and social issues relative to the rapid transition from celluloid to digital exhibition in South Asia, and then position these issues within broader theoretical debates over globalization and cultural hybridity.

Title: The Digital Globe and Climactic Coming Attractions: From Theatrical Release to Theatre of War
Session: Earth Observing Media
Title to Check: The Digital Globe and Climactic Coming Attractions: From Theatrical Release to Theatre of War
Session to Check: Earth Observing Media
Abstract: This paper considers the politics of representation inherent in the emergence of the digital globe. Starting with a consideration of early renaissance globes as separate and distinct cultural objects from the two dimensional forms of cartography they followed, this article goes on to consider the emergence of the digital globe. Like its analogue predecessors, the digital globe is an object symptomatic of the multiple cultural, political, philosophical, ecological and sociological factors that form its foundation. Crucially, beyond occidental perspectives that have structured many dominant cartographic accounts of the earth since the renaissance, this article argues that a multipolar environment of online digital globes are emerging to contest western structures of vision that were intertwined with notions of technoscopic superiority of the twentieth century. Instead what is now emerging is a multiplicity of digital globes that function as theatrical platforms for different and diverse agencies. Here the digital globe is analysed in relation to some of their theatrical functions: as a site of spectacular cinematic attractions, as theatre for the dramatic staging of news media events, as a simulated military theatre of operations, as a lecture theatre where the science of geo-engineering is dramatized and as an operation theatre where the planets rapidly declining health is played out.

Title: The "Feminization" of the Media in Postcommunist Eastern Europe
Session: Women Journalists in Turbulent Times: The Gendered Impact of Historical Shifts on Newsrooms
Title to Check: The "Feminization" of the Media in Postcommunist Eastern Europe
Session to Check: Women Journalists in Turbulent Times: The Gendered Impact of Historical Shifts on Newsrooms
Abstract: Findings in the 2011 Global Report on the Status of Women found women to surpass men in both number and status in a majority of news companies surveyed in the region of Eastern Europe, leading to the perception of news as a feminized field. Women’s presence in media companies in Poland, Hungary, Romania, and Bulgaria, particularly, grew faster than men’s. This presentation problematizes the finding of women’s dominance within the historical framework of communism and in light of events in today’s post-communist era. Factors examined include labor issues under communism, women’s skills levels and adaptability to change, and the shift to a commercialized media system that brought with it an entertainment-orientation in media content and a sensationalism of news. The presentation will also explore why women’s dominance in media fields has done little to erase the underlying patriarchal nature of Eastern European societies.

Title: The Israeli Term for Talk "Tokbek" (Talk-Back - Online Commenting) and its Relevance to the Online Public Sphere
Session: Technologically-Mediated Interactions: Problems and Promises for Civic Engagement and Interpersonal Interactions
Title to Check: The Israeli Term for Talk "Tokbek" (Talk-Back - Online Commenting) and its Relevance to the Online Public Sphere
Session to Check: Technologically-Mediated Interactions: Problems and Promises for Civic Engagement and Interpersonal Interactions
Abstract: Israeli journalistic websites introduced a feature that later became popular elsewhere - the "comments" section where readers can inscribe their responses to the report. This form of commenting received its own term for talk tokbek, derived from the English term “talk-back.” From cultural members' perspective, while the tokbek had unlimited technological potential to promote new modes of civil engagement, it failed in achieving this goal and evolved to an anti-discourse that frequently undermines attempts on constructive dialogue. Grounded in the ethnography of communication, we provide a cultural interpretative framework for the analysis of this discursive failure. The main communicative action of the tokbek is to construct the commenters’ political selves, mainly based on “the Leftist” and “the Rightist” stereotypes. The tokbek discourse thus facilitates a bashing ritual that communicates a radical pessimism about the very possibility of its own communicability. So doing, the tokbek ritual joins similar Israeli cultural performances that substitute democratic deliberation with a pseudo-political venting arena. While not implying that the internet is incapable of promoting a democratic public sphere, we contend that cultural contexts as established through interactions cannot be overlooked when discussing technological advancements and their relevancy to political participation.

Title: The Political Mapping of Korean Twitter Users
Session: Politics Online: International Perspectives
Research Areas: Quantitative - Network Analysis, Deliberation & Political Conversation
Title to Check: The Political Mapping of Korean Twitter Users
Session to Check: Politics Online: International Perspectives
Abstract: This study employs network analysis, while focusing on the discussion of South Korean president, Lee Myung-Bak, to better understand public opinion dynamics occurring on Twitter. More specifically, the study seeks to identify opinion leaders on the discussion network by looking over a longitudinal distribution of tweets that include the president’s name. In so doing, this study analyzed three types of messages: “followed,” “mention,” and “retweet.” The data, collected between November 1, 2011 and April 20, 2012, includes 53,165 twitter users and 1,144,306 lines consisting of three types of relationship. By looking over the density of subgroups classified by their political view, the study also examines whether Twitter users, in their discussion of the president, are likely to be exposed to cross-cutting political views. The findings show that the discussion of Lee Myung-Bak is dominated by liberal Twitter users who already have great influence on the public even offline. Furthermore, Twitter users appear unlikely to interact with those who have opposing political views.

Title: The Role of Conversation in Developing Accurate Political Perceptions: A Multilevel Social Network Approach
Session: Perceptions and Misperceptions: Causes and Consequences
Research Areas: Deliberation & Political Conversation, Quantitative - Network Analysis, Political Knowledge & Sophistication
Title to Check: The Role of Conversation in Developing Accurate Political Perceptions: A Multilevel Social Network Approach
Session to Check: Perceptions and Misperceptions: Causes and Consequences
Abstract: We employ social network data from 25 randomly sampled voluntary associations to understand the factors associated with accurate perceptions of the candidate preferences of fellow group members. We build upon research in communication, political science, social psychology, and social networks to identify relevant predictors. We analyze relationships at the dyadic level, but we also consider the aggregated accuracy of perceptions by ego of alters (“perceptiveness”) and the aggregated accuracy of perception by alters of ego (“explicitness”) regarding political candidate preferences using a multilevel modeling approach. We find relatively low levels of accuracy on average, and differential patterns of prediction of perceptiveness and explicitness. However, there is a consistent and strong link between the frequency of communication (viewed as an indicator of network tie strength) and accuracy both at the dyadic and aggregate levels. However, this relationship is moderated by the homophily of political preferences within the group.

Title: The Ubiquity and Influence of CMC Cues in Social Networking Sites
Session: Nonverbal Cues Exchanges in Online Communications
Research Areas: Computer-Mediated Communication, Social Media, Social Networking Service
Title to Check: The Ubiquity and Influence of CMC Cues in Social Networking Sites
Session to Check: Nonverbal Cues Exchanges in Online Communications
Abstract: A significant portion of the online activities by customers and other organizational stakeholders use text-based computer-mediated communication (CMC). Facebook status updates, Tweets, blog posts and e-mails are used for communicating organizational messages, engaging customers, and spreading electronic word of mouth. It has been suggested that CMC cues are those components of text-based CMC which fulfill a comparable role to that carried out by nonverbal cues in spoken communication. We make use of linguistic and quantitative analyses of several thousand Facebook and Twitter messages to empirically demonstrate the ubiquity and influence of these cues in online messages posted to social networking sites (SNSs). We establish that CMC cues have an influence comparable to that of nonverbal cues in spoken communication by showing that (1) the presence of specific CMC cues is associated with changes in SNS audience engagement and attitude, and (2) there is an inverse relationship between message length and CMC cue density. The paper discusses the theoretical implications for CMC theories such as social information processing, media richness theory, and a series of theories which developed in response to the failure of media richness theory to predict the meteoric success of text-based CMC in organizational and interpersonal communication.

Title: Top Student Paper: The Unobserved Observer: Humphrey Spender's Hidden Camera and the Politics of Visibility in Interwar Britain
Session: Cultural Framing and Communication Practices
Title to Check: Top Student Paper: The Unobserved Observer: Humphrey Spender's Hidden Camera and the Politics of Visibility in Interwar Britain
Session to Check: Cultural Framing and Communication Practices
Abstract: This paper, part of a study of the rise of hidden-camera photography between 1880 and 1945, examines the use of hidden cameras in Britain between the World Wars. Focusing on a central but little-studied figure, the documentary photographer Humphrey Spender, I analyze the politics of representing people--and of being represented--through documentary photography in the media environment of 1930s Britain. Based on archival research as well as formal analysis, this study links Spender’s photography with broader developments in the history of media in the period, including the grassroots sociological research group Mass Observation, the cinematic experimentation of the Continental avant-garde, the British documentary movement, and the rise of photographically illustrated magazines like Picture Post. In so doing, it illuminates a crucial development in the history of photography: a historical moment when the camera was seen to have the capacity to reveal the truth only when it was itself concealed.

Title: Twitards and Tyler’s Van: Antifans, Twilight, and Textuality
Session: Antifandom, Hate, Annoyance, and Dislike in Media Reception
Title to Check: Twitards and Tyler’s Van: Antifans, Twilight, and Textuality
Session to Check: Antifandom, Hate, Annoyance, and Dislike in Media Reception
Abstract:
In “New Audiences, New Textualities” (2003), Gray suggests that scholars should examine what anti-fans dislike about texts, and how they come to that dislike (particularly since their hatred may develop through paratexts instead of texts themselves). Studying anti-fans, then, enables us to bring our focus to an exploration of the expectations and values we have of media texts. Such an exploration is useful for understanding the divergent responses from fans and anti-fans to the Twilight series. Through a sample of 472 anti-Twilighters, collected alongside a larger sample of Twilight fans, we explore anti-fans’ evaluations of the Twilight series (making sense of why their “favorite character” is a van that almost killed the series’ protagonist) and its fans (whom anti-fans call “Twitards”). By comparing the characteristics of anti-Twilighters to Twilight fans, we discuss why the two groups are so polarized, and how anti-Twilighters can extend our knowledge of anti-fans more generally.

Melissa A. Click is assistant professor of communication at the University of Missouri. She is the co-editor of Bitten by Twilight (Peter Lang, 2010). Her work has been published in NYU Press’s Fandom and in Popular Communication, Popular Music & Society, and Women’s Studies in Communication.

Holly Willson Holladay is a doctoral student in communication at the University of Missouri. Her research interests include audience and fan studies, gender, class, and television.

Title: Validating Measures of Health-Related Conversation Content in the Context of Sleep Behavior Among College Students
Session: Communication Influences on Health Behavior and Behavioral Change
Title to Check: Validating Measures of Health-Related Conversation Content in the Context of Sleep Behavior Among College Students
Session to Check: Communication Influences on Health Behavior and Behavioral Change
Abstract: This research examined the validity of new measures of conversation partners and content to predict beliefs about sleep. A convenience sample of undergraduate students (n=375) completed a written questionnaire that asked about the frequency of sleep-related conversation, number of conversation partners, content of sleep-related conversation, and beliefs about sleep behaviors (based on the Integrative Model of Behavior Prediction). Conversations about health-damaging sleep behaviors were associated with the beliefs that sleeping 8-9 hours of sleep per night (a) will produce unfavorable social and academic outcomes and (b) are largely out of one’s behavioral control. Measures of conversation content explained more variance than simple measures of frequency and predicted lower intentions to perform the behavior. Content-specific conversation measures appear to be valid and should be considered in future health communication research.

Title: What Are the Values and Impacts of Public Relations on Business News?: A Survey of Business Journalists on the Use of Information Subsidies and the Determinants of That Use
Session: Public Relations and News
Title to Check: What Are the Values and Impacts of Public Relations on Business News?: A Survey of Business Journalists on the Use of Information Subsidies and the Determinants of That Use
Session to Check: Public Relations and News
Abstract:
The purpose of this study is to explore the use of information sources business journalists rely on and, thus, the value of public relations in the process. Specifically, this study examines (1) the degree to which journalists use public relations materials, and (2) what factors influence the use of public relations materials.

A Web survey was conducted in December 2009 for U.S. business journalists (N = 120).

The results showed that public relations materials were most frequently used as a story’s background information and/or as a minor part of a story that came from another source or from several sources. Among the fourteen factors, journalistic experience, time pressure, ongoing relationships via e-mail and social media, and the perceived value of public relations materials had significant impacts on the degree of use of public relations materials.

Title: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
Title to Check: Who is the Doctor in This House?: Analyzing the Moral Evaluations of Doctors and Medical Students of House M.D.
Session to Check: Paging Dr. Communication: The Intersection of Instructional Communication and Health Communication
